title: Correct the struct name for ModelGen
refactor: grad clipping
body:
@agelas I have made some changes to the gradient clipper:

* I have renamed it from `gradient clipper` to `grad clipping`.
* I have added a new configuration for gradient clipping, which is now included in both Adam and SGD configurations for seamless integration.
* I have also updated the code to use the Tensor API instead of the backend API in the `clip_by_value` function.

title: Feat/conv stride
body:
- [x] Support stride convolution backward
- [X] Support transposed convolution forward

Support for transposed convolution backward will be done in a following PR.

Since transposed convolution backward is not implemented, it's not available as a module yet, it should be exposed when auto diff is fully supported.

body: Remove the necessity of wrapping everything in Arc or Box. If it's required, the builder will do it, which helps reducing verbosity.

title: Add run-doc-test flat in test CI template
Feat/add tensor checks
body:
# Example

```rust
let _ = tensor_2d.index([1..1, 0..2, 0..2]);
````

```bash
thread 'tests::index::tests::should_support_partial_indexing_2d' panicked at '=== Tensor Operation Error ===
  Operation: 'Index'
  Reason:
    1. The provided indexes array has a higher number of dimensions than the current tensor. The indexes array must be smaller or equal to the tensor number of dimensions. Tensor number of dimensions: 2, indexes array lenght 3. 
    2. The provided indexes array has a range where the start index is bigger or equal to its end. The range at dimension '0' starts at '1' and is greater or equal to its end '1'. Tensor shape [2, 3], provided indexes [1..1, 0..2, 0..2]. 
', /home/nathaniel/Projects/burn/burn-tensor/src/tensor/api/base.rs:165:9
```

title: Add init_with for nn modules
body: The transformer model in the text classification example takes around 200ms less to load the weights and run inference than before. (From 1.2 to 1 second)

title: Feat/lr scheduler
body:
fix #142 

## Decisions

Optimizers should not have the learning rate in their configuration since it's not something opaque that should be hidden by implementations. Some frameworks use object oriented patterns with get and set to mutate the optimizer state during training when a learning rate scheduler is used. However I find this error prone and not very Rusty. Therefore, the learning rate is instead passed as parameter to the optimizer when performing a step. Custom training loop can do whatever they want to control the learning rate, but a common way is using a learning rate scheduler, though I created the `LearningRateScheduler` trait. It is quite similar to the `Optimizer` and `Module` trait such as it defines a `Record` associative type to save and load its state.

In order to add the learning rate metric, I had to add the `MetricMetadata` parameter in the `Metric` trait. Those metadata can be used to implement metrics which are not specific to a model output types.

## Questions

I'm still unsure if the `Optimizer` and `LearningRateSchedule` step method should be taking a mutable reference or taking ownership and returning itself.

I'm still unsure if we should use `learning_rate` or the common `lr` abreviation. Learning rate is quite long and since `lr` is commondly used in many frameworks, it might be the right name.

title: Feat/module no grad
body:
The ability to dynamically set the gradient requirements for modules has been added. Previously, it was assumed that every parameter required gradients, which resulted in resetting the graph after each operation at the module level. This was problematic because we might want to execute operations on modules while still tracking operations. To address this, the fork function has been added to modules, which indicates when we want to send a module to another device with an empty graph.

The detach function has been removed from Module because it can lead to mistakes. Instead of using to_device().detach().require_grad(), which would override previous set_require_grad(false), we can call fork, which preserves gradient settings set when creating a module.

The from_inner function has been removed from ADModule. A static method cannot keep track of dynamic gradient configurations. Instead, the function inner(self) has been changed to inner(&self). Additionally, inner may be renamed to valid since it highlights the purpose of the method and is familiar to PyTorch users.

title: Refactor/optim
body:
Refactor how optimizer works.

Now similar to modules, they have their own Record associative type to determine how their state will be saved. There is two optimizer traits, one for simpler implementations and the other more general.

title: Create record derive
body: Generalize the `Record` trait automatic implementation in the `Module` derive into a `Record` derive.

body: The template was provided by git-hub. I added @nathanielsimard's email.

title: Feat: add new tensor ops mask_scatter
body:
Since there's no operation for filling elements by values from another tensor by mask, which will be needed for implementation of softplus, I have written this new operation.

However, considering my poor experience with automatic differentiation, please be careful with the mathematical details this time.

title: Pretty Print Tensors
body: @nathanielsimard I'm new to Rust so I figured I'd give #138 a shot, Let me know if this is somewhere in the ballpark of what you were thinking. I only implemented a pretty print for 2D Tensor structs composed of Ints (or at least that's what I think I did 🙃), and I can generalize to other types later.
